Data.Quote: "When he arrived it was nearly six o'clock, and the sun was setting full and warm, and the red light streamed in through the window and gave more colour to the pale cheeks."
Data.Title: Dracula
Data.Author: Bram Stoker

Data.Quote: Although it was only six o'clock, the night was already dark. The fog, made thicker by its proximity to the Seine, blurred every detail with its ragged veils, punctured at various distances by the reddish glow of lanterns and bars of light escaping from illuminated windows.
Data.Title: Le Club des Hachichins
Data.Author: Théophile Gautier

Data.Quote: Leon waited all day for six o'clock to arrive; when he got to the inn, he found no one there but Monsieur Binet, already at the table.
Data.Title: Madame Bovary
Data.Author: Gustave Flaubert

Data.Quote: Oh oh oh. Six o'clock and the master not home yet
Data.Title: The skin of our teeth
Data.Author: Thornton Wilder

Data.Quote: By Six, the Flood had done— No Tumult there had been
Data.Author: Emily Dickinson

Data.Quote: 6.00 p.m. Have tea
Data.Title: The Curious Incident of the Dog in the Night-time
Data.Author: Mark Haddon

Data.Quote: The winter evening settles down With smell of steaks in passageways. Six o'clock.
Data.Title: Preludes
Data.Author: T S Eliot

Data.Quote: Why shouldn't he be interested in knowing when his father died? He had certainly never said he wasn't. It was his father for fuck's sake; you ought to know, when your father is dead! - On Tuesday, he said again. - At six.
Data.Title: Med Venlig Deltagelse (Condolences)
Data.Author: Erling Jepsen

Data.Quote: King Richard: What is o'clock? Catesby: It is six o'clock, full supper time. King Richard: I will not sup tonight. Give me some ink and paper.
Data.Title: Richard III
Data.Author: William Shakespeare

Data.Quote: When the bells of Calvary Church struck six, she saw Mr and Mrs Biggs hurrying down the front stoop, rushing off to the shops before they closed.
Data.Title: The Interpretation Of Murder
Data.Author: Jed Rubenfeld

Data.Quote: The newspaper snaked through the door and there was suddenly a six o'clock feeling in the house
Data.Title: The Prime of Miss Jean Brodie
Data.Author: Muriel Spark

Data.Quote: 'He said today was no good as he was going to Norwich. But Friday at six o'clock, same as usual.' 'Are you sure he said six o'clock?' she asked, puzzled. 'Quite sure.'
Data.Title: The Go-Between
Data.Author: L.P. Hartley

Data.Quote: "We will make record of it, my Rosannah; every year, as this dear hour chimes from the clock, we will celebrate it with thanksgivings, all the years of our life." "We will, we will, Alonzo!" "Four minutes after six, in the evening, my Rosannah, shall henceforth--"
Data.Title: The Loves of Alonzo Fitz Clarence and Rossanah Ethelton
Data.Author: Mark Twain

Data.Quote: Above it all rose the Houses of Parliament, with the hands of the clock stopped at three minutes past six. It was difficult to believe that all that meant nothing any more, that now it was just a pretentious confection that could decay in peace.
Data.Title: The Day of the Triffids
Data.Author: John Wyndham

Data.Quote: 'Let me see now. You had a drink at the Continental at six ten.' 'Yes.' 'And at six forty-five you were talking to another journalist at the door of the Majestic?' 'Yes, Wilkins. I told you all this, Vigot, before. That night.'
Data.Title: The Quiet American
Data.Author: Graham Greene

Data.Quote: "At a quarter past six he was through with them."
Data.Title: The Photograph
Data.Author: Penelope Lively

Data.Quote: 'Quarter past six,' said Tony. 'He's bound to have told her by now.'
Data.Title: A Handful of Dust
Data.Author: Evelyn Waugh

Data.Quote: "I checked the time on the corner of my screen. 6.15. pm I was never going to finish my essay in forty-five minutes
Data.Title: Girl Missing
Data.Author: Sophie McKenzie

Data.Quote: At twenty-five past six I go into the bathroom and have a wash, then while the Old Lady's busy in the kitchen helping Chris with the washing up I get my coat and nip out down the stairs.
Data.Title: A Kind of Loving
Data.Author: Stan Barstow

Data.Quote: It is six thirty. Now the dark night and the deafening racket of the crickets again engulf the garden and the veranda, all around the house
Data.Title: Jealousy
Data.Author: Alain Robbe-Grillet

Data.Quote: AT five o'clock the two ladies retired to dress, and at half past six Elizabeth was summoned to dinner.
Data.Title: Pride & Prejudice, ch. 8
Data.Author: Jane Austen

Data.Quote: "At six-thirty I left the bar and walked outside. It was getting dark and the big Avenida looked cool and graceful. On the other side were homes that once looked out on the beach. Now they looked out on hotels and most of them had retreated behind tall hedges and walls that cut them off from the street."
Data.Title: The Rum Diary
Data.Author: Hunter S. Thompson

Data.Quote: 6.30 p.m. Watch television or a video
Data.Title: The Curious Incident of the Dog in the Night-time
Data.Author: Mark Haddon

Data.Quote: To a casual visitor it might have seemed that Mr Penicuik, who owned the house, had fallen upon evil days; but two of the three gentlemen assembled in the Saloon at half-past six on a wintry evening of late February were in no danger of falling into this error. They knew that Great-uncle Matthew, who had made a fortune in the large enterprise of draining the Fen-country, was one of the warmest men in England, and suffered merely from a rooted dislike of spending money on anything that did not administer directly to his own comfort.
Data.Title: Cotillion
Data.Author: Georgette Heyer

Data.Quote: It could do no harm, I thought; and I should be far away when the message takes effect, and I wanted to say something to show we were friends. 'Well,' he said, once more across the gap, 'say tomorrow's no good, I'm going to Norwich, but Friday at half-past six, same as usual.'
Data.Title: The Go-Between
Data.Author: L.P. Hartley

Data.Quote: It is around half past six in the evening. Dusk is gathering in the living room, an early dusk due to the fog which has rolled in from the Sound and is like a white curtain drawn down outside the windows.
Data.Title: Long Day's Journey Into Night
Data.Author: Eugene O'Neill

Data.Quote: And then it was 6.35 pm and I heard Father come home in his van and I moved the bed up against the door so he couldn't get in and he came into the house and he and Mother shouted at each other.
Data.Title: The Curious Incident of the Dog in the Night-time
Data.Author: Mark Haddon

Data.Quote: Kaldren pursues me like luminescent shadow. He has chalked up on the gateway '96,688,365,498,702'. Should confuse the mail man. Woke 9:05. To sleep 6:36.
Data.Title: The Voices of Time
Data.Author: JG Ballard

Data.Quote: Having to change 'buses, I allowed plenty of time — in fact, too much; for we arrived at twenty minutes to seven, and Franching, so the servant said, had only just gone up to dress. However, he was down as the clock struck seven; he must have dressed very quickly.
Data.Title: Diary of a Nobody
Data.Author: George & Weedon Grossmith

Data.Quote: Amy: What's that? I thought I saw someone pass the window. What time is it? Charles: Nearly twenty to seven.
Data.Title: The Family Reunion
Data.Author: TS Eliot

Data.Quote: "Six forty-five," called Louie. "Did you hear, Ming," he asked, "did you hear?" "Yes, Taddy, I heard." "What is it?' asked Tommy. "The new baby, listen, the new baby."
Data.Title: The Man Who Loved Children
Data.Author: Christina Stead

Data.Quote: 'Let me see now. You had a drink at the Continental at six ten.' 'Yes.' 'And at six forty-five you were talking to another journalist at the door of the Majestic?' 'Yes, Wilkins. I told you all this, Vigot, before. That night.'
Data.Title: The Quiet American
Data.Author: Graham Greene

Data.Quote: It was a quarter to seven when I letr myself into the office and clicked the light on and picked a piece of paper off the floor. It was a notice from the Green Feather Messenger Service ...
Data.Title: The High Window
Data.Author: Raymond Chandler

Data.Quote: It was time to go see the Lady. When we arrived at her house at ten minutes before seven o'clock, Damaronde answered the door.
Data.Title: Boy's Life
Data.Author: Robert R. McCammon

Data.Quote: At ten minutes to seven Dulcie was ready. She looked at herself in the wrinkly mirror. The reflection was satisfactory. The dark blue dress, fitting without a wrinkle, the hat with its jaunty black feather, the but-slightly-soiled gloves--all representing self- denial, even of food itself--were vastly becoming. Dulcie forgot everything else for a moment except that she was beautiful, and that life was about to lift a corner of its mysterious veil for her to observe its wonders. No gentleman had ever asked her out before. Now she was going for a brief moment into the glitter and exalted show.
Data.Title: The Four Million
Data.Author: O. Henry

Data.Quote: '... You had no reason to think the times important. Indeed how suspicious it would be if you had been completely accurate.' 'Haven't I been?' 'Not quite. It was five to seven that you talked to Wilkins.' 'Another ten minutes.' 'Of course. As I said. And it had only just struck six when you arrived at the Continental.'
Data.Title: The Quiet American
Data.Author: Graham Greene

Data.Quote: The play was set to begin at seven o'clock and finish before sunset. It was 6:55. Beyond the flats we could hear the hockey field filling up. the low rumble got steadily louder - voices, footsteps, the creaking of bleachers, the slamming of car doors in the parking lot. We were each dressed in a floor-length robe, tie-dyed black, gray, and white. The Obscure Object, however, was wearing a white robe. Mr. da Silva's concept was minimal: no maekup, no masks.
Data.Title: Middlesex
Data.Author: Jeffrey Eugenides

Data.Quote: Folded in this triple melody, the audience sat gazing; and beheld gently and approvingly without interrogation, for it seemed inevitable, a box tree in a green tub take the place of the ladies’ dressing-room; while on what seemed to be a wall, was hung a great clock face; the hands pointing to three minutes to the hour; which was seven.'
Data.Title: Between the Acts
Data.Author: Virginia Woolf

Data.Quote: "'Walk fast,' says Perry, 'it's two minutes to seven, and I got to be home by—' "'Oh, shut up,' says I. 'I had an appointment as chief performer at an inquest at seven, and I'm not kicking about not keeping it.'
Data.Title: Roads of Destiny
Data.Author: O. Henry

Data.Quote: Every evening, Michel took the train home, changed at Esbly and usually arrived in Crécy on the 6.33pm train where Annabelle would be waiting at the station
Data.Title: Atomised
Data.Author: Michel Houellebecq
